title: 105_hr2985
content: Aliens are ineligible for visas and excluded from admission for nonpayment of child support. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for failing to pay child support exceeding $5,000 as per the Immigration and Nationality Act. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for failing to pay child support exceeding $5,000 until the payments are satisfied or a payment agreement is approved. The amendment applies to visas issued 180 days after the enactment of the Act. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for failing to pay child support exceeding $5,000 until payments are satisfied or a payment agreement is approved. The amendment applies to visas issued 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to make any alien deportable if they fail to pay child support exceeding $5,000, until payments are made or a payment agreement is approved. This amendment will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3 of the Immigration and Nationality Act states that aliens who fail to pay child support are ineligible for naturalization until payments are made or a payment agreement is approved. This amendment applies to naturalization applications filed 180 days after the enactment of the Act. Immigration officers can serve legal process on alien applicants for admission to enforce child support obligations under State law. The amendment allows immigration officers to serve legal process on alien applicants for admission to enforce child support obligations under State law. This applies to aliens applying for admission to the United States 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment authorizes the Secretary to provide the Immigration and Naturalization Service with information on delinquent child support payments by aliens.
